questions.question: Gestational hypertension is defined as:
What is the minimum cut-off for defining proteinuria in a random urine sample?
questions.explanation: The cut-off for defining proteinuria is ≥30 mg/dl (0.3 g/L) in a random urine sample.Proteinuria in preeclampsia is also defined by:••• ≥0.3 g protein in a 24-hour urine specimen.Random urine protein: creatinine ratio (PCR) ≥0.3 mg protein/mg creatinine• Protein ≥1+ on urine dipstickA urine dipstick is used only if the above quantitative methods are not available.Note: Proteinuria is not an essential criterion to define pre-eclampsia.

questions.question: In a normal pregnancy, when does the remodeling of spiral arteries begin?
questions.explanation: In a normal pregnancy, the remodeling of spiral arteries begins at 12 weeks.Remodeling of arteries includes invasion of arteries by trophoblasts that convert them fromlow-flow, high-resistance to high-flow, low-resistance vessels. These modified vessels are morecapable of meeting the demands of the developing fetus.Uteroplacental vessel development takes place in two stages:The first stage occurs before 12 weeks post-fertilization. During this stage, invasion of spiralarteries up to myometrium occurs.477The second stage occurs between 12-16 weeks. It involves invasion of the endovasculartrophoblasts into the intra-myometrial segments of spiral arteries. Interstitialtrophoblasts surround the arteries.Incomplete trophoblastic invasion leads to pregnancy-induced hypertension (PIH) where thevessels remain in a state of high resistance leading to placental ischemia and release ofinflammatory mediators and vasoactive substances leading to endothelial injury.As the second stage of invasion occurs by 18 weeks, PIH develops after 20 weeks of pregnancy.

questions.question: A 28-year-old G2P1 patient at 17 weeks of gestation comes for a routine antenatal visit. Herblood pressure is 142/94 mm of Hg. A repeat blood pressure after 4 hours is measured to be148/92 mm Hg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: In the above scenario of hypertension in a patient with gestational age <20 weeks, the diagnosisis chronic hypertension.Chronic hypertension is diagnosed when the patient is a known hypertensive (or) BP > 140/90mmHg before 20 weeks of gestation.Gestational hypertension and preeclampsia are only diagnosed after 20 weeks of gestation.

questions.question: Which of the following does not put a patient at an increased risk for preeclampsia?
questions.explanation: Smoking is not a risk factor for pre-eclampsia rather it is protective.Although smoking during pregnancy causes various adverse pregnancy outcomes, it is associatedwith a reduced risk for hypertension in pregnancy.Risk factors for pre-eclampsia are:• Previous history of pre-eclampsia•Primigravida: young or elderly•Family history: Hypertension, pre-eclampsia.••Placental abnormalities:Hyperplacentosis: excessive exposure to chorionic villi (molar pregnancy, twins, diabetes)• Placental ischemia• Thrombophilias: APLA, Protein C, Protein S deficiency, Factor V laden mutation,homocysteinemia•Twin pregnancy• Molar pregnancy• Rh-negative pregnancy• New paternity - A new partner for subsequent pregnancies478

questions.question: Which of the following does not occur in patients developing pre-eclampsia?

options.A: Abnormal trophoblastic invasion of uterine vessels
options.B: Maladaptive immunological tolerance to fetal antigens
options.C: Maladaptation to cardiovascular changes of normal pregnancy
options.D: Increased placental perfusion due to inflammation

questions.explanation: Placental perfusion is reduced in patients developing pre-eclampsia.The development of pre-eclampsia may be explained by:• Abnormal trophoblastic invasion of uterine vessels, leading to decreased placental perfusion.• Maternal inflammatory response directed against foreign fetal antigens leading toimmunological maladaptation.• Maternal maladaptation to cardiovascular and inflammatory changes of normal pregnancy.•Genetic factors and epigenetic influences.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of patients with anincreased risk of pre-eclampsia?

options.A: Low dose aspirin may reduce severity of disease
options.B: Calcium supplementation above RDA reduces the incidence
options.C: Treatment with magnesium lowers endothelin-1 concentrates
options.D: Megadoses of vitamin C has no proven benefit

questions.explanation: Calcium supplementation above the RDA does not reduce the incidence of pre-eclampsia.However, women who have a calcium-deficient state may benefit from calcium supplementationto reduce their risk of preeclampsia.Prophylactic measures for the prevention of pre-eclampsia include low-dose aspirinadministration (50–150 mg/day). It is started after the 1st trimester, continued throughoutpregnancy, and is to be stopped 7 days before labor.Magnesium administration may be beneficial as it lowers endothelin-1 concentrates.There is no role of a low salt diet, anti-oxidants, or vitamin C.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding the pathogenesis of pre-eclampsia?

options.A: Vascular sensitivity to angiotensin 2 is increased
options.C: There is an increase in sFlt-1 levels
options.D: A decrease in the level of soluble endoglin is seen

questions.explanation: In pre-eclampsia, there is an increase in the level of soluble endoglin.Excessive amounts of antiangiogenic factors, increased sensitivity to angiotensin, and loweredangiotensinase levels worsen hypoxia at the uteroplacental interface.Trophoblast of women who develop preeclampsia overproduces at least two antiangiogenicpeptides that enter the maternal circulation. They increase months before clinical preeclampsiadevelops.• Soluble endoglin (sEng) is derived from the placenta and blocks endothelial nitricoxide-dependent vasodilatation. It also inhibits various TGFẞ isoforms from binding toendothelial receptors.•• Soluble Fms-like tyrosine kinase 1 (sFlt-1) is a variant of the Flt-1 receptor for placental growthfactor (PlGF) and for VEGF. Increased maternal sFlt-1 levels inactivate and decrease circulatingfree PlGF and VEGF concentrations, leading to endothelial dysfunction.

questions.question: A 24-year-old primigravida at 22 weeks of gestation came for a regular antenatal checkup.Her BP is 152/96mmHg. Urine analysis shows proteinuria of 3+. All of the following would beconsistent with her probable diagnosis, except:
questions.explanation: 479The given clinical picture is suggestive of pre-eclampsia and low fibronectin is not a feature ofpre-eclampsia.Features associated with pre-eclampsia:• Fibronectin is a glycoprotein associated with vascular endothelial cell basement membrane andis elevated in women with preeclampsia.•⚫ Thrombocytopenia (HELLP syndrome)Hemolysis (HELLP syndrome)• Increased hemoglobin, caused by a decrease in plasma volume.Hemoconcentration is a hallmark of eclampsia. In preeclampsia, hemoconcentration is presentbut usually not marked.

questions.question: Which finding is most likely to be seen in a patient with pre-eclampsia?
questions.explanation: Decreased GFR is seen in pre-eclampsia.During normal pregnancy, renal blood flow and GFR are increased. However, in pre-eclampsia,renal blood flow and GFR decrease due to increased renal afferent arteriolar resistance. Thehallmark renal lesion is glomerular endotheliosis. Diminished filtration causes serum creatininelevels and plasma uric acid concentration levels to rise. The elevation is also due to enhancedtubular reabsorption.The most common system involved in pre-eclampsia is the renal system.Several studies have demonstrated that pre-eclampsia is associated with low urinary calcium. Thisis often used as a predictive test.

questions.question: Ophthalmic manifestations in patients with preeclampsia syndrome include all, except:

options.B: Central vision loss due to temporary scotoma
options.C: Permanent visual loss due to retinal artery occlusion
options.D: Permanent blindness due to serous retinal detachment

questions.explanation: Serous retinal detachment does not cause permanent visual loss.The most common visual symptom of preeclampsia is scotoma.Blindness can be due to occipital cortex edema, Purtscher's retinopathy (retinal ischemia), orretinal detachment. The blindness is mostly reversible and corrects automatically after delivery.Retinal artery occlusion sometimes causes permanent vision loss.

questions.question: A patient, diagnosed with preeclampsia was brought to the emergency room with threeepisodes of generalized tonic-clonic seizures, urinary incontinence, and altered sensorium for3 hours. After stabilization, an MRI revealed the following findings. Which of the following is469true regarding this condition?

options.A: Anterior circulation is most commonly involved
options.B: This lesions may be seen in most pre-eclampsia patients

questions.explanation: The above clinical scenario and radiological image are suggestive of posterior reversibleleukoencephalopathy syndrome (PRES). This condition is usually reversible.Endothelial dysfunction and cerebral autoregulation failure are implicated as etiologies ofPRES. PRES lesions are almost universal in women with eclampsia but less frequent in480pre-eclampsia.PRES is characterized by the following:• Severe headaches• Altered sensorium•Seizures• Visual disturbances.Radiological findings in PRES:•• Hyperintense T2 lesions in the subcortical and cortical regions of the parietal and occipital lobes.• The basal ganglia, brainstem, and cerebellum are commonly involved.• Posterior circulation is commonly involved, and anterior circulation involvement is seen insevere cases.Neurological manifestations of preeclampsia include:• Headaches• Convulsions• Cerebral edema• Blindness•Cerebral hemorrhage.

questions.question: Which of the following are indicators of severe disease in a patient with preeclampsia?
questions.explanation: Among the given statements, the presence of pulmonary edema, scotoma, or epigastric pain isindicative of severe pre-eclampsia.Criteria for diagnosing severe preeclampsia include:Signs and symptoms of significant end-organ dysfunction are:• New-onset cerebral or visual disturbance i.e., photopsia, scotoma, altered mental status,and severe headache• Severe, persistent right upper quadrant or epigastric pain, unresponsive to medication and notaccounted for by an alternative diagnosis (OR) Serum transaminase concentration ≥2 times upperlimit of normal.•Thrombocytopenia with platelets <100,000/microL.• Progressive renal insufficiency (serum creatinine >1.1 mg/dL)• Pulmonary edema.481SystolicBPDiastolicProteinur Signs of end-organ damaBPiage≥160 mmHg≥110 mmHg++/-≥140 mmHg≥90 mmH +/-+g

questions.question: A patient at 32 weeks of gestation with pre-eclampsia is admitted to your ward. All of thefollowing symptoms would warn you of impending eclampsia, except:
questions.explanation: Decreased deep tendon reflex is not a symptom of impending eclampsia. There will be increaseddeep tendon reflex i.e., hyperreflexia.Symptoms and signs of impending eclampsia include:•••Severe occipital or frontal headacheOliguria diminished urine output <400 ml/day-• Epigastric pain• Visual symptoms - blurring, scotomas, blindness• Disturbed sleep⚫ Ankle clonus•• Severe elevation in blood pressure• Pulmonary edema.

questions.question: A G2P1 woman with a history of pre-eclampsia presents at 24 weeks of gestation for anantenatal check-up. You decide to evaluate her risk of developing pre-eclampsia in the presentpregnancy. Which of the following results is not an indicator?

options.A: Absence of diastolic notch on Doppler
options.B: High resistance index in uterine artery Doppler in the second trimester
options.D: Presence of free fetal DNA in maternal serum

questions.explanation: In this above scenario, the absence of a diastolic notch at 24 weeks on Doppler is not a predictorof pre-eclampsia.In normal pregnant women, a diastolic notch in the uterine artery disappears by 24 weeks. Thus,a persistent diastolic notch present in uterine artery flow between 22-24 weeks is predictive ofpreeclampsia.Predictors of preeclampsia:• Free fetal DNA in maternal plasma• Diastolic notch present in uterine artery flow between 22-24 weeks (high resistance index in thesecond trimester).• Average MAP >90 mmHgPredictors no longer used include:• Hemoconcentration• Elevated fibronectin482• Increase in uric acid levels• Hypocalciuria - calcium in urine <12mg/dl in 24 h• Increased homocysteine levels-Roll-over test screening test is done between 28-32 weeks.

questions.question: A 30-year-old G3P2 at 34 weeks of gestation was admitted as her BP was 150/90mmHg andurine dipstick was 2+ on antenatal checkup. Which of the following drugs is not suitable tocontrol BP in this patient?
questions.explanation: Captopril is an ACE inhibitor and it is contraindicated in pregnancy.High BP and proteinuria are diagnostic of preeclampsia. The following drugs are used for themanagement of pre-eclampsia.ACE inhibitors inhibit the conversion of angiotensin I to the potent vasoconstrictor angiotensin-II.When given in the second and third trimesters, they can cause severe fetal malformations such as:• Bony malformations• Persistent PDA• Respiratory distress syndrome• Limb contracture●•Pulmonary hypoplasia.Anti-hypertensives to be avoided in pregnancy include:• ACE inhibitors• Angiotensin receptor blockers• Diuretics (contraindicated as anti-hypertensive but can be given in CCF)•Reserpine• Sodium nitroprusside (used only as a drug of last resort in refractory severe hypertension)• Diazoxide.

questions.question: Which is the drug of choice for controlling BP in a patient with severe pre-eclampsia?
questions.explanation: DrugDoseLabetalol100 mg TID or QIDMethyl-dopa250-500 mg TID orQIDNifedipin10-20 mg BDeHydralazine10-25 mg BD483Intravenous labetalol is the drug of choice for controlling BP in severe pre-eclampsia.It is the first-line agent for urgent control of BP in pregnancy. It is effective, has a rapid onset ofaction, and has a good safety profile.Labetalol is a nonselective ẞ blocker and vascular blocker. It should be avoided in patients withasthma and congestive heart failure due to bronchoconstriction.Option B: Hydralazine causes maternal hypotension and fetal distress.Option C: Nifedipine causes reflex tachycardia and headache in the mother.Option D: In methyldopa, a change in BP is an indirect action. So it is less effective in controllingBP.Note: Experimental antihypertensive drugs for pre-eclampsia treatment are calcitoningene-related peptide (CGRP) and anti-digoxin antibody Fab (DIF). DIF is directed againstendogenous digitalis-like factors, also called cardiotonic steroids.Choice of anti-hypertensives in pregnancyPIH /pre-eclampsia / severe pre-eclampsiaAcute hypertension/Hypertensive crisisChronic hypertension in pregnancyLabetalolIV labetalol, nifedipine, hydralazineLabetalol > methyl dopa.

questions.question: A G3P1A1, preeclamptic patient at 33 weeks of gestation came for a regular antenatalcheck-up. At present, her BP is 130/90 and an NST is reactive. What is the plan ofmanagement for this patient?471
questions.explanation: The scenario is suggestive of mild pre-eclampsia as the patient has a BP of 130/90 mmHg and nofetal compromise. Hence, the plan of management would be to wait till 37 weeks for termination.In all cases of hypertension during pregnancy, the preferred mode of delivery is vaginal. Cesareanis indicated only for any co-existing obstetrical reasons.Hypertensive condition Time of deliveryGestational hypertensionMild pre-eclampsiaSevere pre-eclampsiaEclampsia, HELLP syndrome38-39 weeks≥37 weeks≥34 weeksImmediate termination irrespective of gestational age

questions.question: A 33-week-pregnant lady with pre-eclampsia presents with features suggestive of HELLPsyndrome. Which of the following is false about her condition?

options.A: Corticosteroids aid in increasing platelet count
options.B: It is characterised by microangiopathic hemolysis
options.C: MgSO4 can be used in the management of HELLP syndrome
options.D: Termination of pregnancy is the definitive management

questions.explanation: 484Corticosteroid treatment for thrombocytopenia is not recommended in patients with HELLPsyndrome.HELLP syndrome is a serious complication in pregnancy characterized by HEmolysis, ELevatedliver enzymes, and Low Platelet count. It occurs in 0.5-0.9% of all pregnancies and in 10-20% ofpatients with severe preeclampsia.Management of HELLP syndrome is supportive, including:- Antiseizure prophylaxis with MgSO4- Platelet tansfusion if platelet count <50,000/mm3, FFP transfusion- Plasmapheresis- Immediate termination of pregnancy in the interest of the mother.The most common cause of maternal death in HELLP syndrome is abruptio placenta and DIC.

questions.question: Which among the following is false regarding HELLP syndrome?

options.A: PT, PTT, fibrinogen levels are normal
options.B: All patients with HELLP syndrome have abnormal BP
options.C: Tennessee criteria is used for diagnosis

questions.explanation: 15% of pregnant women with HELLP syndrome have normal blood pressure.HELLP syndrome occurs at 27-37 weeks. PT, PTT, and fibrinogen levels are normal. This differsfrom DIC where PT and PTT are elevated while the plasma fibrinogen level is decreased.Tennessee criteria is used for diagnosis and Mississippi classification is used to grade HELLPsyndrome.• Tennessee criteria for diagnosis of true/complete HELLP• Platelet count <1 lakh/cu mm• AST >70 IU/L,• LDH >600 IU/L•Mississippi classification divides HELLP into 3 grades based on the platelet count.

questions.question: A G2P1 patient at 25 weeks of gestation is brought to the emergency with right upperquadrant pain and one episode of seizure. CBC reveals a Hb of 7.6gm/dl and a platelet countof 70,000/microL. What is the definitive management?
questions.explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of eclampsia and HELLP syndrome. The definitive managementis the termination of pregnancy.In cases of pre-eclampsia, indications for termination of pregnancy, irrespective of gestational age,are as follows:• Eclampsia (give MgSO4 followed by induction of labor)•⚫ HELLP syndrome• Persistent symptoms of severe pre-eclampsia or severe hypertension• Pulmonary edema• Significant renal dysfunction, coagulopathy485•Abruption of placenta• Fetal compromiseIn mild pre-eclampsia, steroids are given and the patient is delivered at 37 weeks.In severe pre-eclampsia:•If pregnancy is >34 weeks - MgSO4 is given for prophylaxis of eclampsia and the pregnancy isterminated.• If pregnancy is at 27-34 weeks - in the absence of contraindications, expectant management isfollowed and the baby is delivered at 34 weeks, as shown below in the flowchart.Clinical management algorithm forsevere pre-eclampsia at <34 weeksSevere preeclampsiaAdmit to labor and deliveryMaternal and fetal assessment- Consider MgSO4Treat dangerous hypertensionContraindications to conservative management• Persistent symptoms or severe hypertension▪ Eclampsia, pulmonary edema, HELLP syndrome- Significant renal dysfunction, coagulopathyAbruptionPreviable fetus- Fetal compromisePresentAbsentDeliverDevelopcontraindicationsInitial 24-48 hour observation- Corticosteroids for lung maturation- Frequent evaluation: vital signs, urine output- Daily lab evaluation for HELLP syndromeDevelopcontraindicationsOngoing inpatient management- Daily maternal assessment- Serial lab evaluation of renal function andfor HELLP syndrome- Daily fetal assessment and evaluation ofserial growth and amnionic fluidDeliver at 34 weeksOMARROW

questions.question: 472A pre-eclamptic patient at 30 weeks of gestation is rushed to the hospital as she suddenly losther vision 1 hour ago. During admission, she has a seizure. Which of the given statements iscorrect?

options.A: Convulsions within 7 days of delivery are called postpartum eclampsia
options.B: Thrombocytosis is likely to be found
options.C: Blindness due to this condition is usually reversible

questions.explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of eclampsia. Blindness due to eclampsia is usually reversible.Blindness due to eclampsia can be due to a central or peripheral cause. It is irreversible only if theetiology is a combination of retinal infarction and bilateral lateral geniculate nuclei lesions.Option A: Convulsions within 48 hours of delivery are called postpartum eclampsia.Option B: The most common hematological finding in pregnancy-induced hypertension isthrombocytopenia.Option D: The seizures are generalized seizures.Note: The most common cause of death in patients with eclampsia is intracerebral hemorrhage.

questions.question: A G3P2 patient with preeclampsia develops seizures and is started on the Pritchard regimen.What level of serum magnesium should be maintained in this patient in order to preventseizures?
questions.explanation: The clinical picture is suggestive of eclampsia and to control fits, optimum serum magnesiumlevels of 4-7 mEq/L have to be maintained.486MgSO4 regimens for management of eclampsia and severe pre-eclampsia:Loading DoseRegimenIntramuscular(Pritchard)Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai)es4 g (20% solution) IV over 3-5 minfollowed by10 g (50%),deep IM (5 g in each buttock)4g IV slow over 15-20 minutMaintenance Dose5 g (50%) IM 4 hourly in alternate buttocks1-2 g/hr IV infusion

questions.question: The mechanism of action of MgS04 includes all, except:

options.C: It reduces motor endplate sensitivity to Ach

questions.explanation: MgSO4 blocks calcium influx, not sodium.Mechanism of action of MgSO4:• It is a membrane stabilizer and acts as a neuroprotector by reducing motor endplate sensitivityto Ach.• It blocks neuronal calcium influx.• It reduces the presynaptic release of the neurotransmitter glutamate.• It blocks glutaminergic NMDA receptors and potentiates adenosine action.

questions.question: Which of the following is an indication to skip the next dose in a patient with severepre-eclampsia taking MgSO4 prophylactically?
questions.explanation: Repeat injections of MgSO4 are given only if knee jerks are present.The next dose of MgSO4 is only given when all signs of magnesium toxicity are absent.Signs of magnesium toxicity:• Loss of deep tendon reflexes•• Decreased respiratory rate (<12 per min)• Urine output <30 ml/hr•Chest pain, heart blockManagement of magnesium toxicity:•Stop magnesium therapy•Estimation of serum magnesium and creatinine levels.• Injection of calcium gluconate 10 ml (10% solution) IVSide effects of MgSO4:• Anuria•Pulmonary edema.487

questions.question: A pregnant woman with pre-eclampsia is started on prophylactic MgSO4 in view of signs ofimpending eclampsia. An hour later, examination reveals RR - 16 breaths/minute and absentpatellar reflexes. What is her plasma concentration of MgSO4 most likely to be?
questions.explanation: Patellar reflexes disappear when plasma magnesium concentration reaches 10 mEq/L. As there isno respiratory depression, the plasma concentration is likely to be 10-12 mEq/L.The disappearance of the patellar reflex is the first sign of impending magnesium toxicity. MgSO4is prophylactically used in impending eclampsia, severe pre-eclampsia, and HELLP syndrome.Signs of magnesium toxicityPlasma concentrations of magnesium (mEq/L)Loss of patellar reflexRespiratory depressionCardiac arrest10-1212-13>30

questions.question: Magnesium sulphate has no role in:

options.A: Prevention of seizures in severe pre-eclampsia
options.B: Prevention of recurrent seizures in eclampsia
options.C: Prevention of RDS in premature baby

questions.explanation: Magnesium sulfate has no role in the prevention of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in apremature baby, where there is a deficit of surfactant (which results in alveolar collapse).Magnesium in the MgSO4 competes with calcium on voltage-gated calcium channels, therebyaltering its uptake and release. Functions of MgSO4 include:• Membrane protector and neuro stabilizer. It is used in the prevention of cerebral palsy in verylow birth weight neonates.• Reduction of motor endplate sensitivity to acetylcholine, and thus is used as an adjunct in themanagement of acute severe asthma in children and adults•Blocking of neuronal calcium influx, and is thus used in the conservative management ofpre-term labor (tocolytic, option D)• Inducing cerebral vasodilatation, dilating the uterine arteries, increasing the production ofendothelial prostacyclin, and inhibiting platelet activation. Hence it is used in the management ofpre-eclampsia (option A) and to prevent progression to eclampsia (option A).

questions.question: A primigravida at 33 weeks of gestation was rushed to the hospital with recurrent seizures.Her husband says that prior to the seizures, she had complained of a headache and visualdisturbances. She was on antihypertensives from the first trimester and there is no history ofneurological disease. Which of the following is true regarding her management?

options.A: First step of management is intravenous MgSO4
options.B: Diazepam is recommended as an anticonvulsant if MgSO4 fails
options.C: Treatment may be based on recommendations from the Magpie trial
options.D: Maternal alkalosis commonly occurs and needs correction

questions.explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of eclampsia and management may be based onrecommendations from the Magpie trial.The Magpie trial showed that prophylactic use of magnesium sulfate lowers the risk of eclampsia.The first step in the management of eclampsia is maintaining the airway, ensuring oxygendelivery to both mother and fetus. Then, MgSO4 is administered to control seizures.488Thiopentone > phenobarbitone may be used to control seizures. No attempt should be made toshorten the convulsion using diazepam as it often leads to thrombophlebitis and respiratorydepression.Maternal acidosis usually occurs and is corrected when present.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding eclampsia?
questions.explanation: Antepartum eclampsia has the worst prognosis and the most common MRI finding of eclampsia issubcortical white matter edema.Antepartum eclampsia is the most common type of eclampsia. It has the highest rate of maternalmortality.The outcome of eclampsia depends on the duration of hypertension and not severity. Themost common cause of death in eclampsia and severe pre-eclampsia is intracranial bleeding.

questions.question: A pregnant lady with PIH was being monitored with bed rest in supine position. Which of thefollowing is a complication of the below representation?
questions.explanation: Supine vena cava syndrome is the complication of the given representation. The image showscompression of the inferior vena cava by the gravid uterus which can sometimes lead to supinehypotension.During late pregnancy, the gravid uterus compresses the great vessels against the hard spine,when the patient is in the supine position. Of the two vessels, the vena cava is compressed, but theaorta, owing to its structure is relatively resistant.Normally, the vena cava compression results in opening up collateral circulation by means ofparavertebral and azygous veins but in some cases, when the collateral circulation fails to openup, the venous return of the heart may be seriously curtailed resulting in hypotension,tachycardia, and syncope and is called supine vena cava syndrome.The normal blood pressure is quickly restored by turning the patient to the lateral position.489
